snippet: Yiddish experts say the preferred spelling of the winning word in the widely televised Scripps National Spelling Bee on Thursday night has historically been kneydl, not knaidel.
abstract: Yiddish experts say the preferred spelling of the winning word in the widely televised Scripps National Spelling Bee on May 30, has historically been kneydl, not knaidel; officials at Merriam-Webster, dictionary’s publisher, defend their choice of spelling as  most common variant of the word from a language that, problematically, is written in  Hebrew, not Roman.

byline.contributor: Julie Turkewitz contributed reporting, and Susan Beachy contributed research.

lead_paragraph: Yiddish experts say the preferred spelling of the winning word in the widely televised Scripps National Spelling Bee on Thursday night has historically been kneydl, not knaidel.

headline.seo: Some Say Spelling of a Winning Word Wasn’t Kosher
headline.main: Some Say the Spelling of a Winning Word Just Wasn’t Kosher
headline.print_headline: Some Say the Spelling of a Winning Word Just Wasn’t Kosher
